data.fullContent: What type of people are good candidates for focus groups? A focus group is a small group of six to 12 people whom researchers bring together to discuss certain products or brands. Because focus groups are easier to organize and easier for participants to accommodate, they are used extensively by market research firms to help uncover customer beliefs and opinions. Focus groups are also used by planners and management to provide feedback on products or services. Because of the intimate conversations in a focus group, participants are known to feel less inhibited than in other, larger groups. This can lead them to open up and reveal their true feelings about brands, products, or services. In business, using focus groups to uncover consumer feelings and opinions often has marketing applications. Companies use focus groups to evaluate existing products, test out new product designs, or gauge the possible success of new product launches.
